title: What readers say Boston Mayor Michelle Wu should prioritize in her next term
author: Annie Jonas
bullets: Mayor Michelle Wu's primary reader concerns are housing affordability and public safety heading into her second term.
Nearly half of poll participants highlighted housing costs and safety as top issues, with 49% choosing these priorities.
Readers suggest Wu consider zoning changes and public safety improvements to address concerns in Boston.

title: Pay transparency is now law in Massachusetts. What does it mean for you?
author: Pattie Hunt Sinacole
bullets: Massachusetts enacted a pay transparency law effective October 29, requiring employers with 25+ employees to disclose pay ranges in job postings.
The law applies to employees being promoted, transferred, or applying for a job and prohibits employer retaliation for pay inquiries.
Employers with 100+ employees must submit annual wage reports, and the Massachusetts Attorney General enforces compliance with potential penalties.

title: Salem woman who ran ‘creepy creations’ shop to plead guilty in Harvard morgue scandal
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: Salem's Katrina Maclean to plead guilty to interstate transport of stolen goods in Harvard morgue human remains scandal.
Maclean allegedly sold stolen body parts from Kat’s Creepy Creations, acquired via former Harvard morgue manager Cedric Lodge.
Under the plea deal, prosecutors will recommend 12 months imprisonment, facing a maximum of 10 years and $250,000 fine.

title: Tell us: What’s the best New England town for a winter weekend getaway?
author: Kristi Palma
bullets: Boston.com invites readers to suggest the best New England town for a winter weekend getaway.
New England offers diverse winter attractions including ski towns, bed and breakfasts, and scenic ice skating.
Notable winter destinations include Boston, Woodstock, Nantucket, Bar Harbor, Portsmouth, Littleton, and Mystic.

title: Boston ranks among best U.S. cities for Thanksgiving — and tops New England
author: Frances Klemm
bullets: Boston ranks 18th in WalletHub's list of top 100 U.S. cities for Thanksgiving.
Boston is the only New England city to make WalletHub’s list due to its restaurant scene.
Boston boasts highest number of restaurants with Yelp ratings of 4.5 stars or higher.

title: Five years after debuting ‘Java with Jimmy,’ host James Hills isn’t slowing down
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: James 'Jimmy' Hills continues to run his livestream show 'Java with Jimmy' five years after its inception.
Hills, an adviser to Mayor Michelle Wu, interviews local officials, organizers, and community members on his show.
Hills aims to expand his platform, possibly creating a community space for recordings and meetings.

title: Roman Anthony earns a third place finish for AL Rookie of the Year
author: Aidan Buchanan
bullets: Roman Anthony of the Boston Red Sox placed third in the AL Rookie of the Year voting.
Oakland's Nick Kurtz won the award unanimously, with teammate Jacob Wilson finishing second.
Anthony hit .292 with 8 HRs and 32 RBIs in 71 games, earning an eight-year, $130 million extension.

title: Federal judge orders release of Fitchburg woman detained by ICE in viral video
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: Judge Stacey D. Neumann ordered the release of Juliana Milena Ojeda Montoya, 24, detained by ICE in Fitchburg.
Ojeda Montoya was arrested after allegedly stabbing a coworker, but claims detention violated her due process rights.
Both sides must file briefs by Nov. 14 on the Laken Riley Act's applicability, concerning immigrant detention issues.

title: How Mass. lawmakers are reacting to the deal that could end the government shutdown
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Massachusetts lawmakers criticize the Senate's deal to end the government shutdown for not extending health care subsidies.
Rep. Seth Moulton opposes the deal and calls for new Democratic leadership in the Senate over health care negotiations.
Several Massachusetts representatives, including Elizabeth Warren and Katherine Clark, vow to vote against the current funding proposal.

title: Boston firefighters battle 2-alarm blaze at multi-family home in Dorchester
author: Madison Lucchesi
bullets: Boston Fire Department extinguished a two-alarm fire at 25 Train St., Dorchester, displacing two residents.
One firefighter was hospitalized; the cause of the fire remains under investigation by the Boston Fire Investigation Unit.
The fire caused approximately $500,000 in damages, with officials monitoring the site for remaining hot spots.
